speaker: CLOTEN
text: Was there ever man had such luck? When I

speaker: CLOTEN
text: kissed the jack, upon an upcast to be hit away? I

speaker: CLOTEN
text: had a hundred pound on ’t. And then a whoreson

speaker: CLOTEN
text: jackanapes must take me up for swearing, as if I

speaker: CLOTEN
text: borrowed mine oaths of him and might not spend

speaker: CLOTEN
text: them at my pleasure.

speaker:
FIRST
               
              LORD
text: What got he by that? You have broke his

speaker:
FIRST
               
              LORD
text: pate with your bowl.

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: If his wit had been like him that

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: broke it, it would have run all out.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: When a gentleman is disposed to swear, it is

speaker: CLOTEN
text: not for any standers-by to curtail his oaths, ha?

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text:
No, my lord,
                 
                (
                aside
                )
               nor crop the ears

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: of them.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: Whoreson dog! I gave him satisfaction. Would

speaker: CLOTEN
text: he had been one of my rank.

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: To have smelled like a fool.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: I am not vexed more at anything in th’ Earth.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: A pox on ’t! I had rather not be so noble as I am.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: They dare not fight with me because of the Queen

speaker: CLOTEN
text: my mother. Every jack-slave hath his bellyful of

speaker: CLOTEN
text: fighting, and I must go up and down like a cock

speaker: CLOTEN
text: that nobody can match.

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: You are cock and capon too, and

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: you crow cock with your comb on.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: Sayest thou?

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: It is not fit your Lordship should undertake

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: every companion that you give offense to.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: No, I know that, but it is fit I should commit

speaker: CLOTEN
text: offense to my inferiors.

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: Ay, it is fit for your Lordship only.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: Why, so I say.

speaker:
FIRST
               
              LORD
text: Did you hear of a stranger that’s come to

speaker:
FIRST
               
              LORD
text: court tonight?

speaker: CLOTEN
text: A stranger, and I not know on ’t?

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: He’s a strange fellow himself and

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: knows it not.

speaker:
FIRST
               
              LORD
text: There’s an Italian come, and ’tis thought

speaker:
FIRST
               
              LORD
text: one of Leonatus’ friends.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: Leonatus? A banished rascal; and he’s another,

speaker: CLOTEN
text: whatsoever he be. Who told you of this stranger?

speaker:
FIRST
               
              LORD
text: One of your Lordship’s pages.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: Is it fit I went to look upon him? Is there no

speaker: CLOTEN
text: derogation in ’t?

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: You cannot derogate, my lord.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: Not easily, I think.

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: You are a fool granted; therefore

speaker:
SECOND
               
              LORD
text: your issues, being foolish, do not derogate.

speaker: CLOTEN
text: Come, I’ll go see this Italian. What I have lost

speaker: CLOTEN
text: today at bowls I’ll win tonight of him. Come, go.
